reviews.advice: Introducing complimentary meals or refreshments could further enhance the workplace environment.
reviews.cons: I haven’t experienced any downsides here. It’s a great place to work.
reviews.pros: eBay offers a great work-life balance, with wonderful people to collaborate with. The leaders are knowledgeable, supportive, and truly understanding. They give you the space and encouragement to grow, both personally and professionally. It feels like a second home, and I genuinely love being part of the eBay family.
Work Life Balance and decent work

reviews.advice: Define clear priorities and say no to more, focus on quality and not quantity,  appreciate and take care of employees. Put customer experience over profits (its how you'll stay relevant and provide value for them so they stay customers, you can make profits without customers.
reviews.cons: Overworked, unreasonable deadlines,  lack of structure, lack of focus on priorities,  and lot of firefighting or just hurry up and do.
reviews.pros: Pay, some benefits, flexible remote and in office
reviews.summary: Lost care for customer and employee

reviews.advice: Less hierarchy, encourage more  bottoms up contribution
reviews.cons: Depending on the office location, sometimes people are not the smartest. I've encountered senior or staff level engineers who cannot solve problems that they'd be expected to at the level. Planning cycle is hell and really pointless. Company is really large so there are often duplicate projects or people working on overlapping things.
reviews.pros: I am in an org that is relatively product led, with great product leadership (from twitter, meta,etc). I get to work on products that are really interesting. The people are super kind and work life balance is great.
reviews.summary: Good PM experience depending on the org

reviews.cons:
Generally, a mess of a company. It felt like a startup in some ways and was slow to move, like a behemoth corporation in other ways. (Think of it as the worst of both worlds.)

Teams are global, and spread across many time zones and regions. This caused great difficulty in task sharing. Also, the differences in work culture and employment regulations has a general negative impact on the U.S. employees. PTO and sick time rules are not consistent across the globe, so this results in the U.S. employees getting leaned on harder than others. (Yes, I know pay scales are different.) My point is, it felt unbalanced a lot of the time.

Project management and oversight was a mess, leaving it to project management software, people managers, and the contributing project team members to manage things on their own.

Their knowledge systems were generally out of date, overly complex, and rarely updated. This was a well-known fact, but was never addressed. Finding the right answer to anything was just left to knowing the right people to ask and an exercise in frustration.

Lastly, the most recent round of layoffs (10% of the company in total) seemed harsh, flippant, and overly reactive, especially considering what they did shortly after with a HUGE technology purchase that never paid off while I was there. 

My biggest reason for leaving though?

The layoffs. Once a company does it, it becomes easier for them to do it again, and it destroys most teams in the long run. I saw no future at eBay.
reviews.pros:
Well known brand
Job flexibility in some groups
Standard benefits
reviews.summary: Messy and Unorganized for such a Well Known Brand

reviews.cons: Reorgs all the time. I averaged about one every 6 months. I guess that's what happens at a dinosaur of a company. Constant confusion on who's doing what, oftentimes with teams you've never heard of apparently doing the same thing (or trying to). Frequent directional changes, and in recent years mass layoffs.
reviews.pros: A digestible environment to be in. Unlike some other companies I've worked at, this was very much chill compared to some of the dog-eat-dog worlds I've been in. People felt like they were working together with you hand-in-hand, and you could create genuine bonds and relationships with those around you.

reviews.cons: rate of innovation slower than expected
reviews.pros: good mission, and diverse activities to support
reviews.summary: good work life balance and appears to be ready for another good run

reviews.cons: Behind tech trends compare to other tech companies.
reviews.pros: Good work life balance. Chill work envinroment.

reviews.cons: Low pay, lack of trabing and development
reviews.pros: Remote work and good work life balance

reviews.advice: Have faith in the workers who do the nitty gritty everyday. They are the ones who know and understand the business better than anyone. Give them opportunities to succeed.
reviews.cons: There is no room for growth at all, especially outside of the Authenticity Guarantee program. Employees will apply for positions outside of the program and not receive them, when they are basically doing the job at hand. They talk about “hiring from within” and still continue to hire outside of the company - people who don’t even understand authentication and the operations. It puts a strain on the operation and those who are in it everyday. There is a disconnect between departments, too many hands in every pot so nothing gets done, ever. After sneaker con was acquired, they should have re-interviewed each person who was coming over, especially in management. In an operation, if someone isn’t working, let them go. Enough of the 50 million chances when they are not doing their job correctly.  eBay could be the best in this realm of work, but they continue to shoot themselves in the foot.
reviews.pros: Great company to work for, especially within the Authentication department. Co-workers are passionate about what they do and the talent is unmatched. You learn a lot from a big corporate company and there are a ton of opportunities to meet and learn from people from all over.
reviews.summary: Great company to work for but no growth.
